passages.text: August 29, 2025 03:30 AM GMT

The CBE resumed rate cuts with 200bp cut this week. Next we expect the NBP to deliver 25bp of easing but see risks for more cautious forward guidance. We expect inflation for August to tick down to \(2.6\%\) in the Czech Republic and to \(32.6\%\) in Turkey.

Poland | NBP to ease into autumn: We continue to expect the NBP to lower its key policy rate by 25bp to \(4.75\%\) in its upcoming September 3 meeting. That said, recent communication from MPC members points to risks that the central bank communication could turn more cautious for the rest of the year.

- Inflation dropped significantly to \(3.1\%\) in July and we now expect it to decrease further to \(2.9\%\) in August, against \(3\%\) previously. Core inflation continued to decline gradually, reaching \(3.3\%\) down from \(3.4\%\) in June.- Poland's economy maintained a healthy pace of growth in 2Q25, expanding by \(0.8\%\) Y, up from \(0.7\%\) in 1Q25, resulting in an improvement in the annual growth rate to \(3.4\%\) Y from \(3.2\%\) Y in 1Q25. While high-frequency data for July was mixed, we initiate our GDP growth tracker at \(0.6\%\) Q but the slowdown in wage growth and trade tensions points to downside risks to growth for the rest of the year, we think.- While we also continue to expect one more 25bp rate cut in November, we see possible catalysts that could result in the NBP remaining on hold for the rest of the year: potential hikes in the banking CIT, larger-than-planned excise duty and sugar tax increases, the extension of the electricity price caps, and pending decisions from the energy regulator on new regulated electricity prices.
South Africa | Finality on Eskom tariffs Egypt | A 200bp cut to resume easing Turkey | August inflation in focus Czech Republic | Inflation to tick down again Hungary | No change in the NBH stance
Israel | BOI still in wait- and- see mode
EEMEA in numbers and pictures | Calendar | Chart Gallery | Economic Forecasts | Inflation and Rates Monitor | In Case You Missed it...
MORGAN STANLEY & CO. INTERNATIONAL PLC Georgi Deyanov
RMB MORGAN STANLEY PROPRIETARY LIMITED
MORGAN STANLEY & CO. INTERNATIONAL PLC
Recent Research Highlights
Poland: NBP Preview: Easing into Autumn
Hungary: NBH Review: No Shift in Stance
South Africa : Less Words, More Pictures: The Roadmap to \(3\%\)
Egypt: CBE Preview: Resuming Cuts
Turkey: Inflation Report: A Stronger
Czech Republic: CNB Review: Home Cooking
South Africa: The Roadmap Toward \(3\%\)
South Africa: SARB: Cuts on Both Fronts
South Africa: Quick Take on the Fiscal Anchor
Turkey: CBT Review: A More Front- Loaded Cut
Hungary: NBH Review: From Solid to Liquid
CEEMEA: Views from Across the Pond
Egypt: A Close Call in Rates Following Lower
Exhibit 1: Poland: Domestic inflation has started to trend lower while imported inflation remains slightly negative
Source: Haver Analytics, Morgan Stanley Research: Fore more details on methodology see here.
For important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

South Africa | Finality on Eskom Tariffs: South Africa's energy regulator will allow Eskom to raise electricity prices by more than previously permitted over the next two financial years after the parties reached a settlement following a legal dispute. Prices will now rise by \(8.76\%\) in the next financial year, up from \(5.36\%\) , and by \(8.83\%\) the year thereafter, up from \(6.19\%\) :

- This has very little impact on our inflation forecasts. With a category weight of just \(4\%\) the marginal amount just isn't large enough to warrant a forecast revision. Rather, we view finality on the matter as a positive as there was some market concern that the potential increases could be far larger.- From the SARB's perspective the outcome could be more interesting. Their baseline assumed something closer to \(11\%\) in July vs an outcome of \(8.6\%\) . Accordingly, their 2H25 forecast of \(10.4\%\) now looks high compared to what is likely to be something closer to \(9\%\) . For 2H26 their forecast of \(6.0\%\) (which essentially reflects the original Eskom award of \(5.5\%\) ) could be slightly higher.- Net-net, we think this is a wash, with price increases slightly lower this year and slightly higher next year. The SARB forecast probably doesn't change much.

Egypt | A 200bp cut to resume easing: The CBE cut its policy rate by 200bp to \(22\%\) , delivering a larger cut than Bloomberg and Reuters consensus for 100bp, but closer to our forecast for 150bp. As we wrote in our preview, we thought the MPC had room to cut up to 200bp at this meeting without risking disinflation or foreign portfolio investments. Also, local newspapers had put the broader consensus within a range of a 100 to 200bp cut, with some expectations for even a larger, 300bp, cut. Hence, we do not see this 200bp cut as a dovish surprise that would change our views.

- The statement mentioned a broad-based easing in price dynamics over the past two months, which is in line with our analysis. The CBE sees inflation continuing to ease, averaging between 14 percent and 15 percent in 2025.- As a rationale behind its 200bp cut, the MPC assessed that "improving underlying (inflation) dynamics relative to previous months, and more supportive exchange rate developments have created room for a measured resumption of monetary easing".- In terms of forward guidance, the MPC reiterated a meeting-by-meeting approach, and said that it will reassess the scale and pace of monetary easing guided by the forecast trajectory, incoming data and the prevailing balance of risks.- We expect a total of 200bp cuts in the remaining three meetings until year-end, and see the policy rate reaching 20% by December versus inflation at 14%Y.- Policy rate adjusted by realised inflation now stands at 8pp, which we think is still sufficiently high to support disinflation and the local currency, barring any significant global or geopolitical shocks.

Turkey | August inflation in focus: We expect monthly inflation to come in at \(1.8\%\) in August, bringing year- on- year inflation down to \(32.6\%\) from \(33.5\%\) July. Forks survey of 22 economists has a median expectation of \(1.8\%\) , similar to our forecast. Based on past seasonal coefficients for forecast implies a seasonally adjusted monthly inflation rate around \(2.2\%\) (SA) - lower than July's \(2.7\%\) (SA) but higher than the May- June average of \(2\%\) (SA).

- We expect core-C at \(1.6\%\) , implying a decline in year-on-year terms to \(32.9\%\) from \(34.7\%\) . We expect a moderate core goods inflation thanks to a slower pace of lira depreciation in August, but we see services exerting upward pressure on core inflation.- Within services, we expect rent inflation to remain elevated given the seasonality related to contract renewals. We would not rule out an upside surprise in services, and consequently in core inflation, should the rise in university education fees feed into the index more strongly in August rather than in September, as we assume in our forecast.- We expect a higher food inflation than in the previous three months at \(1.6\%\) , bringing the year-on-year inflation rate in this group to \(31.4\%\) from \(28\%\) , mainly on processed food items.- Barring any significant upside surprise in the CPI (to above \(2.2\%\) ) and its decomposition (i.e. stronger core inflation momentum), we think the CBT will deliver another 300bp cut in its next MPC meeting on September 11.- While we expect 200bp cuts in both the October and December meetings, to end the year at a \(36\%\) policy rate, this will depend on
the alignment between the inflation outlook and the CBT's intermediate target of \(16\%\) for end- 26, as emphasised by the new framework introduced in the latest Inflation Report.
Czech Republic | Inflation to tick down against the expected the flash CPI print for August to tick down to \(2.6\%\) from \(2.7\%\) in July.

- We see food inflation easing to \(4.2\%\) from \(5.2\%\) in July but alcohol and tobacco inflation rising to \(4.6\%\) from \(4.4\%\) , resulting in an overall easing of the combined food, alcohol and tobacco inflation metric to \(4.3\%\) from \(4.9\%\) in July.- While the flash estimate data does not enable us to calculate the CNB-defined core inflation, we expect it to remain flat at \(2.7\%\) , which would translate into a 10bp downward miss against the CNB's current forecast for \(2.8\%\) .- Note that headline inflation for July at \(2.7\%\) was already 10bp lower than the CNB forecast. If our forecast turns out to be correct, inflation will keep tracking 10bp below the CNB's forecast for \(2.7\%\) .- We see risks to our forecast as skewed slightly to the downside as there are indications that food price pressures might have eased more than we expect.

Hungary | No change in the NBH stance: The NBH kept its key policy rate unchanged at \(6.50\%\) , in line with our and consensus expectations. Despite the subdued economic and slower wage growth, the MPC continued to aim to ensure financial markets stability as well as anchoring inflation expectations through maintaining restrictive monetary policy.

- Compared to July, the August statement added that the fiscal measures announced over the course of the summer are expected to have a moderate effect on the budget in 2025 but to impede the reduction of public debt. However, from 2026 onwards, these measures could have an increasingly negative effect on the budget deficit, according to the NBH.- We continue to expect inflation to start easing from the current level in November and December and to reach the target temporarily in 1Q26. Hence, we maintain our forecast for the NBH to lower its policy rate to \(6\%\) at the end of 2025 and \(4.75\%\) at the end of 2026, starting with a 25bp rate cut in November this year. Still, uncertainty about fiscal policy in 2026 and the FX path ahead, in light of the upcoming parliamentary elections in April 2026, coupled with tariff-related risks, continues to skew the risks to our policy rate forecasts to the NBH remaining on hold. We will be focusing on the upcoming core meeting in September for hints of the possibility of the central bank starting to see room for monetary policy easing.
Israel | BOI still in wait- and- see mode: The BOI kept its key policy rate unchanged at \(4.50\%\) in line with our and consensus expectations.

- While the central bank highlighted that inflation is expected to converge within the tolerance band within the \(1 - 3\%\) Y target range in the coming months, the MPC saw several risks for a possible acceleration of inflation or for it not converging to the target range: geopolitical developments and their impact on economic activity, an increase in demand alongside supply constraints, and worsening global terms of trade.- Following the \(0.9\%\) Q contraction in 2Q25 GDP, the BOI updated its output gap estimate to \(-5.4\%\) from \(-4\%\) previously. The central bank elaborated that excluding the impact from the Iran conflict, GDP growth was positive but below the long-term potential growth.- The statement highlighted that geopolitical risks continue to create uncertainty and if they intensify this could translate into supply restrictions continuing to weigh on the recovery of economic activity, and hence growth may be more moderate, and the budget deficit and inflation may be higher.- In terms of inflation data, the July CPI print came out at \(3.1\%\) , down from \(3.3\%\) in June and slightly below our forecast for \(3.2\%\) but in line with consensus expectations. Yet, inflation excluding energy, fruits and vegetables ticked up to \(3.5\%\) from \(3.4\%\) . Similarly, core inflation that also excludes government-initiated price changes ticked up to \(2.6\%\) from \(2.5\%\) in June. Looking ahead, we expect inflation to ease to \(2.7\%\) in September but to move up slightly in 4Q25 to \(2.9\%\) on average and thus to remain uncomfortably close to the upper bound of the tolerance band.- Despite inflation likely to remain close to the upper bound of the tolerance band in 4Q25, we maintain our call for the BOI to deliver one 25bp rate cut in that quarter in anticipation of inflation easing further in 1H26. With the Fed also likely to engage in an easing cycle as soon as September, risks to our forecast are now skewed towards the BOI engaging in an easing cycle also at its September meeting. We maintain our below- consensus call for the policy rate to reach \(3.25\%\) in 2026.
